78827291C59F440283ABDA921342DCB8.description: Create artworks in the style of an American artist.

149CEEF805084325B98CC480D506AD3C.description: Discuss how the evolution of art in the United States of America was a reflection of culture and historical events.

41B865AC3A1149728A8E49B08AA0D4BF.description: View artworks from the Enlightenment and the French Revolution as an inspiration for talking about and creating art.

0A9A13FA25E94859B95EE6E04AB2C3AE.description: Use visual arts vocabulary when responding to or sharing opinions about artworks

EA644711EFEF4333BF7EC01FB9AC1A82.description: Create artworks that reflect visual and popular culture.

E03E50AC5A034D9387DC840844C4906D.description: Visual art traditions existed prior to the colonization of the United States of America and evolved as more people came to the land

1BFC5E964A334186BED45E3D212D60B9.description: The way in which the visual arts are understood and appreciated has changed throughout history.

3BD64AB91BF04460AEE77F0D8E5D2E66.description: Appreciation of visual arts can change through active reflection and experience with artworks

136E8D172D03430DA7A9BAE7F337A137.description: During the Harlem Renaissance, black artists were free to express black lives and identity for the first time in American history, as seen in Aaron Douglas, The Judgment Day, 1939 James Lesesne Wells, Looking Upward, 1928 Norman Lewis, Jazz, c. 1938

D7F64F7B449F4138B60ED0B6F52AD262.description: The Harlem Renaissance (1917-1930s) was a rich artistic and cultural art movement in the United States of America

F9DDA6561F644C5D8731866644AD32CE.description: American artworks and artists are famous for their contributions to visual culture and modern art, and can include Andy Warhol, pop art Jackson Pollock, abstract expressionism Jacob Lawrence, Harlem Renaissance Mark Rothko, colour field painting

FC74B14508E340F4977A82A35E2BE52B.description: The American Revolution was based on the ideals of the Enlightenment, and the neoclassical style was reflected in the architecture of the United States during this time, as seen in The White House, in Washington, DC

4B7BC82857574B1DBD59687347420913.description: As the United States of America became colonized, people brought with them a large and varied tradition of arts and crafts, which became known as folk art

3FC6913FD1684C9E8514A3FD1BAAB423.description: Before colonization of the United States of America, the Indigenous people had rich and historical traditions of visual arts that continue to be celebrated today.

CFF32314FCC748A594FA530B73608E67.description: Neoclassicism reflected the culture of the common people during the French Revolution because it embraced the ideals of freedom and equality.

49F909E32D2240E28513E17F341E387A.description: Neoclassical art emphasized realism through the use of symmetry and carefully organized compositions, as seen in JacquesLouis David, The Oath of the Horatii, c. 1784.

00B46636105248138E170C6A291C45B1.description: Artworks during this time were also heavily influenced by the discovery of Pompeii, which reignited an interest in ancient Greek and Roman art and architecture

5F665586019F488B88BF7D384C817D12.description: The neoclassical art movement that emerged during the period of the Enlightenment featured the ideas of freedom, democracy, and reason

DF3764E28B144892BF598E19DAE27ABA.description: The Rococo movement was rejected because it featured artworks that did not reflect the lifestyle of the common people

EE7B5C8358E54650A8CFA063C34D0FF0.description: The Enlightenment period rejected the previous art movement, Rococo, which was elaborate and extravagant as profiled in the Palace of Versailles, in France

92BC0F68C8564ACD9F077CA712B3B6EA.description: Visual culture can be a subject matter or theme that includes ways of seeing and visually representing the world, including animation, digital media, and advertisements

AEE5C05A895942BCBF9DEC249BE30EDF.description: Popular (pop) culture evolved from artistic traditions and is appreciated as a form of expression from the people for the people

F1CCFAA17E95430E8688CE7F7AF60B10.description: Appreciation can shape individual artistry, curiosity, and engagement in visual arts

8CF07A85095D4F63976CE36AB0ADADFB.description: Appreciation of artworks can inform future decisions regarding participation as an artist and a viewer of art.

050BDF3E1BC74A73822C3008FF264E4C.description: Students relate change to historical events and appreciation of visual arts practices.

6627B863529744E79D381F6EE4653357.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in visual arts can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great artworks, the artists who create them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

080F1972BE044B14BAC27DC1743048F3.description: Reflect on strengths and areas for growth as an artist.

6203EE4E122E461B968D301C4C8E7C76.description: Describe how feedback was incorporated to clarify or enhance artistic intention.

265E24CCED534DABA3601AD8FF2644C0.description: Take creative risks as a means to address design challenges

3DF6EB6AEC8C4CDC8D611EFFC7073074.description: Practise art-making skills, techniques, and methods as a means to strengthen artistic expression.

2C2A643CF63F4E90B2A013D68ECE331F.description: Create artworks with the intention of communicating a subject or a theme.

BE54F1B6FD9646C282EF6801355DD21D.description: Create artworks that intentionally reflect realistic, symbolic, or abstract representations.

FA8DB75180E648BF85CC2961FC916990.description: Determine what tools, media, or techniques are required to achieve artistic intention in artworks.

3167B4331C65489A955B93E9B6F92868.description: Give credit to other artists when using their ideas as an inspiration

C5737238E78C4D509B00FAC7FA7E891D.description: Create two- or three-dimensional artworks in the style of a particular artist or art movement

E8DA3DE667784A47BABAB93C74720BCC.description: Make intentional artistic choices to create a desired effect in artworks

E2E2EAD376504F1A98DF71A87C81054C.description: Create a title and description for artworks.

9AE0D3AB5CFA4CBDA169E9433A5529BA.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of the media used to convey artistic intention.

7C9291DD296046A3BD0F162D6AA13F43.description: Incorporate the principles of design to clarify intention

255CA166CB394E4393FD5308336458D0.description: Explore various ways in which artworks can be shared or displayed.

2FD7D50CF024420CA0D080B1F1E76CFF.description: Create a plan for making art.

3C06F50E6CDB4B53AF6AB036EADAD25D.description: Growth as an artist can occur when one engages with the creative process in new and meaningful ways.

4478EC9F25584E6EA31372D05357EEDD.description: Some artworks may not have an obvious intention that can be interpreted.

F12169D6B6794F44878976B081BFBE45.description: An artist's intention may emphasize process over product.

528F6F84182A490FA45CFC044C6CC394.description: Artists can intentionally create art that is realistic, symbolic, or abstract.

01967A27EEA6424E8181EBB7F4193BA5.description: Intention can be linked to the purposeful creation, expression, or appreciation of artworks.

D3513197CE6C4DEB8CD436170417EA76.description: Intention refers to what an artist means to express.

674905203CF84BE3BCFAA7B4DA9E3259.description: Intention becomes evident to the artist and audience when artworks have structure and organization

4207F9ADC0A84588AD2AE6FE2750DDD1.description: Communicating intention can involve taking creative risks and employing creative processes

EE1F2BF19B264603825FA43B69948B39.description: Art can be intentionally created for enjoyment, creative expression, or as a way to explore new techniques, skills, or media

E2975280E81A47EC9C59D666E03FC6AA.description: Intentionally practising art skills and techniques can improve artistic expression.

845E30C3A26A46D185ADCF6927A56B33.description: Appreciating artworks can include citing other artists' work when borrowing their ideas as inspiration and asking for permission to replicate other artists' work

49545AA694BF48CD841BAF3E3F4E35E7.description: Art movements throughout history featured artists known for their artistic style or intentional use of media and can include Andy Warhol(pop art), Banksy (an anonymous England-based street artist), Diego Rivera (who established the mural movement in Mexican and international art), Frida Kahlo (Mexican painter known for self-portraits), Jack Kirby (comic book artist), Pablo Picasso (Spanish painter, sculptor, printmaker, and ceramicist known for the Cubism movement).

D7D0FBFABC1E4AAC9E70B00D08626259.description: Analogous colours can be used intentionally to harmonize the colours of a composition

059CDC0024F74A17844DFACEFC2920E4.description: Mixed media is where various materials and media are intentionally combined within artworks, as seen in Jane Ash Poitras, Prayer Ties My People, 2000

3F8BF9C471B04D719A494043E56D4123.description: An artist can intentionally combine, alter, or omit certain elements of art to create an effect, including illusions of movement, depth, distance, and mass emotion or mood symbolic representations perspective

28B2035A42604D978CB35C870C115FB1.description: Artworks can be created to intentionally communicate a subject or theme

A4B6D6F5E03A40BD939B4CD5422EF947.description: Artworks may be interpreted in a way that differs from what the artist intended

14611AE53EC545B9BCCBE41B0CBBB6C8.description: The way in which artworks are displayed can either detract from or contribute to highlighting the intention of the artist.

20C5B9082D1B49BBAF10D23D5F36FB26.description: Organization can include balance of positive forms in relation to negative space

39215C9DE6094A219BD54F07B505F39A.description: Spatial organization can clarify intention of artworks when line, shape, space, colour, and value are employed.

C8C1EF272B5B4B29915051374A03091E.description: Intention can be clear when a plan for creating art is made, including the use of the colour wheel a colour palette a view finder research a grid to divide the work surface into equal ratios for determining proportions

EDEC253810854CF39844982C4F6C1B41.description: An artist can communicate intention in artworks by giving artworks a title creating descriptions for art talking about art

9974F84A8D9C4AD0B43DE82CCDEBF4E9.description: Intention can be linked to what media an artist uses

55E638273BE64AC1AA85978621604017.description: Students express intention as an integral part of artistic expression in visual arts

7F3574534B8C4B1DB2DD094BD1303E88.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented through artworks that draw upon foundational visual arts knowledge

927ED438607647BCA69004CDFE521961.description: Use principles of design as a way to organize artistic ideas.

5D32A1888F0C40D49E814AF1384E4558.description: Use visual arts vocabulary to discuss how artists use balance to create a focal point in artworks.

DC453441BA9D4A828F087845B660A4B1.description: Discuss the relationship between balance and unity in artworks.

43678BCA8FD7440094EF7D604B14C625.description: Make artistic choices in the creation of artworks.

20C7FB6AE9BA4BB0B77A4822FF84425D.description: Explore and discuss various ways that artworks can be organized to communicate meaning or style

01F7A54CC7F048E692AED5C4701D4832.description: Consider how spatial organization contributes to perspective in artworks.

84FB3519505F400EAD39D1D7D5C8ACD4.description: Explore techniques for activating or suggesting space in artworks.

9074C1350E10424E945690199F213766.description: Create artworks that imply spaces beyond the edges of the picture plane.

1550F5D31BE245A3B9A4861368E363F0.description: Explore ways that the use of space in artworks can create illusions.

945CE9A07EEF42D789B7D68698CD6EC2.description: Use visual arts vocabulary to discuss how spatial organization is achieved in artworks.

6885DE2D4B2047D18D84758D226E31ED.description: Identify and employ analogous colour schemes in artworks

88FF684FA49C450998B9C145B0B4A455.description: Explore and apply the colour combinations used to create tertiary colours.

27454A8DDC674EF4AFC98F3449A19DDF.description: Differentiate between warm and cool colours on a colour wheel

548D2552DC7F48F993C19FD13CD1AB7B.description: Use the colour wheel to plan and create artworks

52C72D563E894335AE82D8982FF8FF50.description: Adjust value to suggest an effect of light or shadow.

59A55B6BAB8E44D8975CD646CE8A611C.description: Explore the effects that the elements of art may have on one another when combined in artworks

B5C837FD0C614DF7838199375B4ABDE3.description: Explore how the elements of art can be employed and organized within various media.

0B4E67CFE0E74D20B880EDFFC1C75E45.description: Organization relies on the principles of design to promote unity in artworks.

266B0B5245B14ACFA91CE7F9108DEE15.description: Artistic choice can influence organization in artworks.

33A549F4038B46DC939693D934407F4D.description: Spatial organization occupies, activates, or suggests space within an artwork.

0F1AF06E5C3D47CEA06A388C6007672A.description: The colour wheel can be a planning tool for creating a colour palette.

C6504BE1DC044695A9789471142EC323.description: The organization of a colour wheel can vary and may indicate colour value and intensity.

2067114F75194B92931DC071CA8A642A.description: The organization of colour relationships is illustrated on a colour wheel.

D571707155D442CF97EEB4A88836A3A3.description: Organization is the interaction between the elements of art

C800F897A50443F4B9CF87430B28C27F.description: The principles of design can clarify organization of the elements of art, as seen in Frida Kahlo, SelfPortrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird, 1940

4364B152AC4E48D79BE18195CC7C2787.description: Radial balance can create a strong focal point and an illusion of movement and depth, as seen in Alex Janvier, Morning Star, 1993

709FB5F7B5C743B4A25B2CA694C88FDD.description: Balance is a principle of design that can enhance unity by using pattern and repetition symmetrical, asymmetrical, and radial balance colour values and opaque and transparent colour placement of shapes

3EECD0F2AD5F40E69AFC1088428BAB36.description: Unity is when all parts of the design work in harmony to create a sense of completeness, as seen in Brian Jungen, Vienna, 2003 Prudence Heward, At the Theatre, 1928

2154E0679FC44EB5AC02768B5CFF9E66.description: Artistic choices can reveal an artist's style, as seen in Bill Reid, Spirit of Haida Gwaii, c. 1986-1991

B803AA5EDCE240A683C2CEAB4745AFCB.description: There is an infinite number of ways to organize the elements of art.

BF36F06F4EC844E7874D70ED8F9FA97F.description: Artistic choices can include communication of symbolic or literal meaning choice of media, tools, techniques, and materials subject matter to be represented use of the elements of art and principles of design

F93899B9851548F1B9087918B1BF1094.description: Techniques such as the following can create illusions of space in artworks: placement of an object on the picture plane overlapping shapes varying size of shapes adjusting value and colour

52B52E8E4E684B748BD148BA452C0C05.description: The use of space to create illusion and focal points can be seen in Thomas Cole, The Oxbow (also known as View from Mount Holyoke, Northampton, Massachusetts, after a Thunderstorm), c. 1836.

AF54C7BA18AA4AE68DB1A1B2F173B5ED.description: Spatial organization of value can include light and shadow gradations into light, dark, and mid-tones

ADC920466661426C9A320768FD15D9EC.description: Spatial organization of colour can include cool and dull colours giving the illusion of objects that are far away warm and bright colours giving the illusion of objects that are closer

24D601F2C81F4D38B85631D8229C83C1.description: Organization regarding space can include positive space, negative space, proportion depth and dimension pictorial space, including foreground, middle ground, background actual space (opened or closed) in three-dimensional objects or the environment

8DFA237B540B4A06821E80D8EB392AC0.description: Spatial organization of shape can include overlapping shapes placing shapes near horizon lines to give an illusion of depth adjusting size of shapes

33FD6B50ACE14899B64C0C75B1B88174.description: Spatial organization of line can include atmospheric perspective linear perspective and one- or two-point perspective to create an illusion of space in twodimensional works of art horizon lines point of view, including bird�seye view and close-ups

B57B5CFE1CF741B18E2123C03C1B7080.description: Spatial organization can apply to line, shape, space, colour, and value

EEDC8BC289B2442FA1BA8D1D5AE803BA.description: Analogous colours create a colour scheme that can bring harmony and balance to artworks, as seen in William Trost Richards, Newport Coast, 1902 Yisa Akinbolaji, Wisdom Thread, n.d.

322A8C2F310D4B61B7BE62F5ED39EB39.description: Analogous colours create a colour scheme that can bring harmony and balance to artworks, as seen in William Trost Richards, Newport Coast, 1902 Yisa Akinbolaji, Wisdom Thread, n.d.

A9166A98A5AC45EDA7E9459FBC351153.description: Tertiary colours are created when a primary colour is mixed in equal proportions to an adjacent secondary colour

4A2A01163408490FAE45F1018DB39744.description: The warm colours on a colour wheel appear opposite cool colours

DC73B5A6B34D48AF854DB3DF015FB7EE.description: Media in art can include found objects and materials from the surrounding environment

AC0D431BCFD0401C8F0AC5357263F384.description: Organization of the elements of art can include line/implied line, line weight, value, direction, contour, physical characteristics of line shape and form/proportion, geometric, organic, positive, negative, static, dynamic, physical characteristics, basic, complex colour/tertiary, analogous, monochromatic, complementary, primary, secondary, warm and cool, intensity, gradation, tints and shades, colour accents, transparent and opaque texture/actual and simulated texture space/focal point, illusions, symmetry, perspective value/shading to suggest form or mass, gradation, colour

D1BF761F9FBB45CEA6F67A6FB545ACE1.description: When working with different media in art, considerations regarding organization of the elements of art may be required.

99C2F167D7784D6F89C015A8FC421581.description: Students investigate organization as a structural component in artworks.

D476E450E1C940F8B02D958EF1CBB010.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Visual arts literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles.
